notes_1: "On 13 June 2011, the African Union High Implementation Panel (AUHIP) held a round of negotiations to tackle remaining contentious issues between Sudan and South Sudan."

agreement name: Agreement Between The Government of the Republic of Sudan and The Sudan People's Liberation Movement on Temporary Arrangements for the Administration and Security of the Abyei Area
notes_1: "On 20 June 2011, the AUHIP facilitated an agreement between the parties on temporary arrangements for Abyei."

agreement name: Agreement on the Joint Political and Security Mechanism and the Joint Position Paper on Border Security
notes_1: "On 29 June 2011, following mediation by the AUHIP, the two sides formally signed the Agreement on the Joint Political and Security Mechanism and the Joint Position Paper on Border Security."
"On 29 July 2011, the AUHIP mediated between Sudan and South Sudan on security arrangement regarding the shared border between the parties."

agreement name: Agreement on the Border Monitoring Support Mission
notes_1: "A series of meetings with both conflict parties were held from 30 July to 31 July 2011. Although no progress was made regarding the delineation of the Safe Demilitarized Border Zone, the parties reached the Agreement on the Border Monitoring Support Mission."

agreement name: Peace Agreement
notes_1: Fighting soon erupted again. South Sudan became independent on 9 July 2011. This was the result of a referendum held six months earlier, in which an overwhelming majority of the South Sudanese population voted for independence. The Forces of George Athor subsequently renamed themselves into the South Sudan Democratic Movement/Army (SSDM/A). The new regime in Juba was mainly challenged by the SSDM/A led by George Athor in the Jonglei province. A round of negotiations between George Athor and South Sudanese President Salva Kiir on 20 November in Kenya, mediated by the South Sudan Council of Churches, led to the conclusion of a peace agreement. In spite of this agreement, Athor stepped up the SSDM/A’s armed attacks on government targets in early December 2011. Athor was killed on 19 December 2011, reportedly while entering South Sudan from Uganda. Peter Kuol Chol Awan became the new leader of the SSDM/A.

"From December 2011 onwards, tensions over oil payments exacerbated. Sudan took control of the oil flowing from South Sudan as payment for transporting the oil from South Sudan to Port Sudan. South Sudan subsequently unilaterally halted its oil production in January 2012. This escalatory succession of events prompted IGAD to hold a peace conference on 26 January 2012. IGAD Chair Meles Zenawai acted as the chief mediator at this conference. No progress was made at this conference."

agreement name: Memorandum of Understanding on Non-Aggression and Cooperation
notes_1: "Another round of negotiations, mediated by the AUHIP with support from the UN, led to the signing of the Memorandum of Understanding on Non-Aggression and Cooperation on 10 February 2012. However, fighting between Sudanese and South Sudanese security forces continued along their border."

agreement name: Memorandum of Understanding on Non-Aggression and Cooperation
notes_1: "Another round of negotiations, mediated by the AUHIP with support from the UN, led to the signing of the Memorandum of Understanding on Non-Aggression and Cooperation on 10 February 2012. However, fighting between Sudanese and South Sudanese security forces continued along their border."
note_2: The term 'other' refers to the UN's support of the mediation process.

notes_1: "With support from the UN Special Envoy, the AUHIP mediated between the conflict parties in March 2012."
"With support from the UN Special Envoy, the AUHIP mediated between the conflict parties in March 2012."

agreement name: Two initial framework agreements
notes_1: "A round of negotiations mediated by the AUHIP led to the signing of two initial framework agreement, one on the issue of nationality and another agreement on border demarcation in Addis Ababa on 10 April 2012. With tensions remaining high, South Sudan surrounded Sudan’s largest oilfield in April 2012."

"The AU Peace and Security Council established a roadmap to peace between the parties on 24 April 2012. This plan officially placed the AUHIP in charge of mediation with the aim to resolve multiple issues of contention such as Abyei, the Safe Demilitarized Border Zone, and oil in the span on three months. The UN Security Council adopted this plan in Resolution 2046 adopted on 2 May 2012.  The conflict parties subsequently engaged in negotiations mediated by AUHIP Chairman Thabo Mbeki in Addis Ababa on 29 May 2012."
"Another round of negotiations led by the AU was held in Addis Ababa on 22 June 2012."
"Another meeting led by the AU in Addis Ababa was held on 4 September 2012."
"The AUHIP went on to propose its own draft agreement on 21 September 2012. South Sudan accepted this agreement, but Sudan rejected it."

agreement name: Cooperation Agreement
notes_1: "The Presidents of both countries attended a round of negotiations mediated by AUHIP in Addis Ababa from 23 to 27 September 2012. This culminated in the signing of the Cooperation Agreement and eight other agreements. This re-opened food trade between the countries and Sudan released 19 South Sudanese prisoners. On 27 September 2012, Sudan and South Sudan signed the Implementation Modalities for Security Arrangements, which was aimed facilitating the implementation of the Agreement on Security Arrangements."

agreement name: Cooperation Agreement
notes_1: The Ethiopian Prime Minister, Haile Mariam Dessalegne, signed the Cooperation Agreement on 27 September 2012 as a witness to the agreement. Addis Ababa played host to these negotiations.

agreement name: Implementation Modalities for Security Arrangements
notes_1: "The Presidents of both countries attended a round of negotiations mediated by AUHIP in Addis Ababa from 23 to 27 September 2012. This culminated in the signing of the Cooperation Agreement and eight other agreements. This re-opened food trade between the countries and Sudan released 19 South Sudanese prisoners. On 27 September 2012, Sudan and South Sudan signed the Implementation Modalities for Security Arrangements, which was aimed facilitating the implementation of the Agreement on Security Arrangements."
"To implement this agreement, the Joint Political and Security Mechanism convened in Juba from 5 to 7 November 2012."
note_2: The term 'other' refers to the convening of meetings of the Joint Political and Security Mechanism.

notes_1: "To implement this agreement, the Joint Political and Security Mechanism convened in Juba from 5 to 7 November 2012."
note_2: The term 'other' refers to the convening and supporting of meetings of the Joint Political and Security Mechanism.

notes_1: "The mechanism met once again on 19 December 2012, with support from AUHIP and the UN. At this meeting, the countries worked with the Force Commander of the United Nations Interim Security Force for Abyei (UNISFA) to create an implementation matrix."
note_2: The term 'other' refers to the convening and supporting of meetings of the Joint Political and Security Mechanism.

notes_1: "The mechanism met once again on 19 December 2012, with support from AUHIP and the UN. At this meeting, the countries worked with the Force Commander of the United Nations Interim Security Force for Abyei (UNISFA) to create an implementation matrix."
note_2: The term 'other' refers to the convening and supporting of meetings of the Joint Political and Security Mechanism.

notes_1: "The African Union High Implementation Panel (AUHIP) mediated between South Sudan and Sudan in Addis Ababa from 3 to 5 January 2013.  The conflict parties agreed that the implementation of previously concluded agreements needed to be sped up."

"From 13 to 18 January 2013, the Presidents of both countries attended a summit facilitated by the AUHIP. This effort did not result in any peace agreement, but the parties agreed to the implementation matrix put together in December 2012."
note_2: The term 'other' refers to the convening of a summit.

notes_1: "Sudan and South Sudan engaged in negotiations mediated by the AUHIP on 12 March 2013. The conflict parties agreed to resume oil production and create the demilitarized zone."

"A major milestone was reached the following month when Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir visited South Sudanese President Kiir Mayardit for the first time in the new country. During this visit, on 12 April 2013, the two sides agreed to create a joint high-level committee."
note_2: The African Union supported the meeting between the leaders of Sudan and South Sudan.

notes_1: "The conflict parties engaged in negotiations mediated by the AUHIP from 24 to 27 April 2013. Throughout May and July 2013, tensions over accusations between both sides concerning support for rebel groups began to increase. On 22 July 2013, the African Union established an ad hoc mechanism to investigate these claims.  In late July 2013, Sudan halted oil transportation in response to South Sudanese support to the Sudan People’s Liberation Army/Movement – North (SPLM/A-N). The Sudan President had met with AUHIP delegates before announcing this decision."
note_2: The term 'other' refers to the AU's establishment of a mechanism to investigate accusations of the two governments' support of rebels.

notes_1: "On 28 November 2013, Sudanese and South Sudanese security delegates met for negotiations mediated by the AUHIP in Khartoum. The AUHIP was unable to make progress on creating the demilitarized security zone during this round of negotiations. Armed fighting between Sudan and South Sudan resumed in mid-December."

"The South Sudan Democratic Movement/Army (SSDM/A) - Cobra Faction has its roots in the SSDM/A, though it did not form as a splinter faction. The SSDM/A - Cobra Faction was established by David Yau Yau in 2013, a year after the SSDM/A forces had been integrated into the national army following mediation by the South Sudan Council of Churches. In 2011, the South Sudanese government had offered a presidential amnesty to Yau Yau and his fighters in return to their integration in the government army. However, this peace was short-lived and Yau Yau defected to Sudan in April 2012. Sudan’s National Intelligence and Security Services facilitated repeated airdrops of weapons and ammunition across different locations throughout 2012 and 2013. Yau Yau’s defection to Sudan escalated into a full-blown insurgency in 2013, with many Murle joining the rebellion in response to the government’s disarmament campaign. The government issued an ultimatum to respond to an amnesty on 5 June 2013. However, armed clashes between the conflict parties continued. Yau Yau and his Murle fighters objected to mediation by the South Sudan Council of Churches because Archbishop Daniel Deng being a Dinka Bor. In the first half of 2013, a mediation effort was conducted by a British defense contractor of AEGIS Defense Services (UK), James Ellery, hired by the South Sudanese government. This mediation effort was conducted in the first three months of 2013 and was aimed at initiating formal negotiations, but the mediation effort failed. UNMISS engaged the government, but also supported Ellery’s effort, providing both logistics and security. Ellery met with Yau Yau six time at various place in Pibor county, but Yau Yau did not agree to official negotiations. Governments forces launched a military operation on 5 March in spite of efforts by the UNMISS leadership to persuade the government to refrain from such an operation. In addition, UNMISS flew Ellery to Pibor county on 13 March to get Yau Yau’s consent to a 48-hour ceasefire, but this effort failed."

note_2: The term 'other' refers to Jame Ellery's attempts to initiate formal mediation and negotiations.

notes_1: "The Ellery mediation effort was conducted in the first three months of 2013 and was aimed at initiating formal negotiations, but the mediation effort failed. UNMISS engaged the government, but also supported Ellery’s effort, providing both logistics and security."
note_2: The term 'other' refers to UNMISS's attempt to engage the Sudanese governments in negotiations.

notes_1: "A mediation attempt to initiate official negotiations by local Murle elites and interlocutors close to the Juba government on 19 and 20 May 2013 also failed."
note_2: The term 'other' refers to the Murle elites' attempts to initiate negotiations.

notes_1: "A mediation team of three nationally respected church officials from Equatoria – namely Catholic bishop Paride Taban, along with Bishop Paul Benjamin Yugusuk of the Episcopal Church and Bishop Arkanjelo Wani Lemi of the African Inland Church – was initiated at a meeting in Addis Ababa in August 2013. This mediation effort, dubbed the Church Leaders’ Mediation Initiative (CLMI), was supported by the Dutch NGO PAX and also received logistical support from Norwegian Church Aid and UNMISS. During the meeting in Addis Ababa in August 2013, the bishops agreed with representatives of the SSDM/A-Cobra Faction to enter into negotiations with the government. With President Kiir’s blessing, the bishops and the Presbyterian Murle pastor Orozu Lokine subsequently met with Yau Yau in Kongor in September 2013. The onset of the civil war between the South Sudanese government and the Sudan People’s Liberation Army/Movement-In Opposition (SPLM/A-IO) strengthened the government’s commitment to a deal with Yau Yau as the government needed soldiers to fight the SPLM/A-IO, pushing the government to make concessions in favor of Yau Yau at the expense of key government actors in Jonglei state."

notes_1: "The SSDM/A led by Olony accepted a ceasefire and an amnesty by the government following mediation by the Shilluk reth (King) in June 2013. Negotiations on the terms of integrating the SSDM/A fighters into the national army subsequently continued in July and August 2013."
"Negotiations on the terms of integrating the SSDM/A fighters into the national army subsequently continued in July and August 2013."

agreement name: Integration of rebel leaders into national army
notes_1: "Following another round of negotiations in November 2013, President Kiir issued a decree on 25 November 2013 that confirmed the reintegration and commissioning of Major General Johnson Olony into the government forces. The SSDM/A remained loyal to the government until early 2015, when they defected to the SPLM/A-IO."

"The armed conflict between Sudan People’s Liberation Movement/Army - In Opposition (SPLM/A-IO) and the Government of South Sudan started in mid-December 2013, when two different factions within the Presidential guard clashed in Juba. One faction was loyal to President Salva Kiir, while the other faction was loyal to the former vice-president Riek Machar. Machar had been ousted from the government in July 2013. In mid-December, President Kiir accused Riek Machar of conducting a coup d’état, but this accusation later proved to be unsubstantiated. The accusation is widely seen as a pretext for crack down on Machar and pushing all Nuer troops out of Juba, after which Nuer civilians were targeted. Armed clashes between the conflict parties quickly spread to other areas, in particular to Bor, Malakal, and Bentiu. In response to the armed conflict, Salva Kiir also detained a group of eleven high-profile individuals, accusing them of conspiring with Riek Machar to overthrow the government. The political prisoners were all senior SPLM/A party members who had begun to openly criticize the president in 2013. This group has commonly been referred to as the “former detainees” after the first seven were released in January 2013 and the remaining four were released in in May 2014. As soon as the war broke out, Uganda intervened in the civil war in support of the South Sudanese government, while Sudan supported the SPLM/A-IO with weapons and ammunition. A delegation from the Inter-Governmental Authority on Development (IGAD), which had mediated an end to the civil war in Sudan in 2005, visited Juba between 19 to 21 December 2013 for pre-negotiations with President Kiir and other relevant stakeholders to obtain a first-hand understanding of the crisis, to explore possible ways to resolve the crisis, and to make the conflict parties agree on official negotiations. This IGAD delegation was supported by the UN and the AU."

This group has commonly been referred to as the “former detainees” after the first seven were released in January 2013 and the remaining four were released in in May 2014. As soon as the war broke out, Uganda intervened in the civil war in support of the South Sudanese government, while Sudan supported the SPLM/A-IO with weapons and ammunition. A delegation from the Inter-Governmental Authority on Development (IGAD), which had mediated an end to the civil war in Sudan in 2005, visited Juba between 19 to 21 December 2013 for pre-negotiations with President Kiir and other relevant stakeholders to obtain a first-hand understanding of the crisis, to explore possible ways to resolve the crisis, and to make the conflict parties agree on official negotiations. This IGAD delegation was supported by the UN and the AU."

"On 26 December, a second IGAD delegation – led by the President of Kenya, Uhuru Kenyatta, and the Prime Minister of Ethiopia, Hailemariam Dessalegn – visited Juba for peace talks with the President of South Sudan, members of the Cabinet, and the detained a group of eleven high-profile individuals. The IGAD delegation also tried to further probe into the root causes of the conflict and discuss how best to address it. IGAD held an extraordinary summit in Nairobi on 27 December 2013, where three special envoys – Ambassador Seyoum Mesfin of Ethiopia, General Lazaro Sumbeiywo of Kenya, and General Mohamed Ahmed Mustapha al-Dabi of the Sudan – were appointed to support a resolution of the crisis."

agreement name: Ceasefire
notes_1: "The peace process between the government and the SSDM/A-Cobra Faction was brought to Addis Ababa in January 2014. This mediation effort was conducted by the South Sudanese Church Leaders Mediation Initiative (CLMI). Hizkias Assefa, an Ethiopian professor and mediator, acted as the chief mediator during this peace process. The conflict parties signed a ceasefire on 7 January 2014."

agreement name: Ceasefire
notes_1: "IGAD began to mediate direct negotiations between the conflict parties in early 2014. Seyoum Mesfin, who had been the Ethiopian Minister of Foreign Affairs from 1991 until September 2010, was the chief mediator of the peace process. A first round of negotiations took place in Addis Ababa between 2 and 23 January 2014. These negotiations mainly focused on the conclusion of a ceasefire, as well as on the release of some political prisoners taken by the government. The mediation team led by Mesfin considered a ceasefire unlikely to hold unless underlying political grievances were addressed, but they deemed that a reduction in violence was necessary to create the space for substantial negotiations. Hence, the negotiations first focused on the conclusion of a ceasefire. The conflict parties signed a ceasefire on 23 January 2014, which took effect the next day.  The ceasefire committed the conflict parties to end offensive operations, freeze their forces in place, and refrain from attacks against civilians. The ceasefire also established a monitoring and verification mechanism."

agreement name: Agreement for a buffer zone with join units deployed for monitoring
notes_1: "On 14 October 2015, Sudan and South Sudan convened for peace talks in Addis Abba. At this round of talks, Sudan and South Sudan agreed to establish a buffer zone with join units deployed for monitoring."

notes_1: "On 12 January 2015, the conflict parties signed another ceasefire in the IGAD-led mediation process, as well committed themselves to accelerate efforts to reach an agreement based on the formation of a transitional government."

agreement name: Arusha Agreement
notes_1: "Negotiations in Arusha  between 9 to 19 January 2015 brought together President Salva Kiir representing the SPLM/A-In Government, Rick Riek Machar representing the SPLM/A-In Opposition, and Deng Alor Kuol representing the SPLM/A-Former Detainees. John Samuel Malecela, the Vice Chairman of Tanzania’s ruling party the Chama Cha Mapinduzi (CCM), and Abdulrahman Kinana, the CCM General-Secretary, acted as the chief mediators at this round of negotiations in Arusha. The negotiations led to the signing of the Agreement on the Reunification of the Sudan People’s Liberation Movement (Arusha Agreement) on 21 January 2015."

"The South Sudanese government and the SPLM/A-IO met in Addis Ababa on 27 and 28 January 2015 for two days of  IGAD-mediated negotiations prior to the IGAD Head of States Summit on 29 January.  These negotiations focused on power-sharing. The IGAD mediation team proposed to make Riek Machar vice-president again, but keeping James Wani Igga as a second vice-president. Politicians from Equatoria expressed opposition to this proposal, asserting that Igga should hold a more senior position to Riek Machar in a future power-sharing agreement."

"Another round of IGAD-led negotiations in Addis Abba started on 23 February 2015. Prior to the start of this round of negotiations, both the AU and IGAD threatened sanctions against South Sudan if a comprehensive power sharing deal is not reached by 5 March. One major disagreement during the negotiations was that the SPLM/A-IO demanded the creation of two separate armies in the country during the transitional period, with the SPLM/A-IO fighters being officially recognized as a separate army. The negotiations broke down on 6 March 2015."

"The IGAD mediation effort resumed in June, but was officially reconfigured as “IGAD Plus” in June 2015, expanding the mediation team to also include representatives from five African Union member states, the UN, the Troika (US, UK, and Norway), the EU, and China. A new round of negotiations was initiated in Addis Ababa on 9 June 2015. This round of negotiations ended on 25 June, with agreement that the IGAD mediation would circulate a “compromise agreement” in July, which was the product of negotiations and consultations since January 2014."

"At a new round of negotiations that had started with a summit in Addis Ababa on 27 July chaired by President Barack Obama, it was decided that the conflict parties would have until 17 August 2015 to sign a final peace agreement. Several amendments were subsequently negotiated on the basis of the draft agreement. For instance, the conflict parties agreed that the deadline for the complete integration of the SPLM/A-IO forces into the national army would be within 30 months of signing of the agreement, instead of the 18 months proposed by the mediators."
note_2: The term 'other' refers to the holding of a summit.

agreement name: Agreement on the Resolution of the Conflict in the Republic of South Sudan
notes_1: "Both Riek Machar and a representative of the former detainees signed the Agreement on the Resolution of the Conflict in the Republic of South Sudan (ARCSS) in Addis Ababa on 17 August 2015. However, Salva Kiir indicated he was not ready to sign the agreement. The mediation team subsequently gave him and his negotiation team two additional weeks to return to Juba and secure support for the deal. Following this decision, the US introduced a draft resolution in the UN Security Council which threatened an arms embargo and targeted sanctions against South Sudan if the government failed to sign the agreement deal. Nine days later, Kiir signed the agreement at a ceremony in Juba in the presence of IGAD leaders. In October 2015, a Joint Monitoring and Evaluation Commission (JMEC), consisting of members of the conflict parties and IGAD Plus, was set up to oversee the implementation of the agreement. IGAD appointed the former president of Bostwana Festus Mogae to head JMEC. In late October, the top military commanders of the government forces and the SPLM/A-IO attended a five-day workshop held in Addis Ababa to discuss security arrangements associated with the implementation of the peace agreement."
note_2: The term 'other' refers to the establishment of the Joint Monitoring and Evaluation Commission (JMEC).

agreement name: Agreement on the Resolution of the Conflict in the Republic of South Sudan
notes_1: "Both Riek Machar and a representative of the former detainees signed the Agreement on the Resolution of the Conflict in the Republic of South Sudan (ARCSS) in Addis Ababa on 17 August 2015. However, Salva Kiir indicated he was not ready to sign the agreement. The mediation team subsequently gave him and his negotiation team two additional weeks to return to Juba and secure support for the deal. Following this decision, the US introduced a draft resolution in the UN Security Council which threatened an arms embargo and targeted sanctions against South Sudan if the government failed to sign the agreement deal. Nine days later, Kiir signed the agreement at a ceremony in Juba in the presence of IGAD leaders. In October 2015, a Joint Monitoring and Evaluation Commission (JMEC), consisting of members of the conflict parties and IGAD Plus, was set up to oversee the implementation of the agreement. IGAD appointed the former president of Bostwana Festus Mogae to head JMEC. In late October, the top military commanders of the government forces and the SPLM/A-IO attended a five-day workshop held in Addis Ababa to discuss security arrangements associated with the implementation of the peace agreement."
note_2: The term 'other' refers to the establishment of the Joint Monitoring and Evaluation Commission (JMEC).

agreement name: Outcome of the Meeting of the Principal Signatory Parties to the Agreement on Planning Implementation of the provisions in Chapter II of the Agreement
notes_1: "Another round of IGAD-led negotiations led to the signing of the Outcome of the Meeting of the Principal Signatory Parties to the Agreement on Planning Implementation of the provisions in Chapter II of the Agreement on 3 November 2015. This Agreement concerns the details on the implementation of the Transitional Government of National Unity (TGONU) and the Transitional National Assembly (TNA), as well as the adoption of the transitional constitution. The agreement also specified that the SPLM/A-IO was allowed to deploy 1,410 security personel in Juba and the government 3,420 security personnel."

"On 27 June 2015, President Salva Kiir and SPLM/A-IO leader Riek Machar conducted a consultative meeting in Nairobi under the auspices of President Kenyatta of Kenya to review elements of the proposed peace agreement."

"The ARCSS included a political power-sharing provision. To this purpose, Machar returned to Juba in April 2016. However, problems with the implementation of the ARCSS were already apparent prior to Machar’s return. Kiir had cast aside the power-sharing formula of the ARCSS in October 2015 through creating 28 states instead of ten states. In addition, in violation to the agreement, Chief of Staff Paul Malong had secretly brought a Dinka militia to Juba. With tensions increasing, fighting between the conflict parties eventually resumed in July 2016. This effectively suspended the peace process. Following the clashes, President Kiir issued a decree on an immediate ceasefire in the country on 11 July 2016. Yet, fighting continued. Riek Machar subsequently fled to the Democratic Republic of Congo while under attack of ground forces and helicopter gunships. Taban Deng Gai sought the support of some disgruntled SPLM/A-IO generals, after which Kiir appointed Taban Deng Gai as the vice president, replacing Machar. Riek Machar was later put under house arrest in South Africa. However, most of the SPLM/A-IO remained loyal to Machar. JMEC chairman Festus Mogae reported in October 2016 that “near-daily violations” of the ceasefire by both parties, warning that these could 'trigger an uncontrolled escalation of violence.'"

agreement name: Entebbe Declaration on the Operationalization of the Arusha Agreement on the Reunification of the SPLM
notes_1: "Building on the Arusha Agreement that had been concluded in January 2015, Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni mediated a round of negotiations between the three factions with the SPLM/A in July 2017. This round of negotiations involving the SPLM/A-In Government, the SPLM/A-IO, and the SPLM/A-Former Detainees led to the signing of the Entebbe Declaration on the Operationalization of the Arusha Agreement on the Reunification of the SPLM on 27 July 2017. This agreement established a working group to revitalize and operationalize the implementation of the Arusha Agreement, trying to reunify the SPLM/A. In addition. IGAD tried “revitalize” the peace process from mid-2017 onwards.  The IGAD leaders endorsed a plan to kick-start the peace process at the 31st Extra-ordinary Summit of IGAD Assembly of Heads of State on 12 June 2017. IGAD announced on 1  October 2017 that it would resume the formal peace process to bring peace to South Sudan."

agreement name: Cairo Declaration on the Reunification of the Sudan People’s Liberation Movement (SPLM)
notes_1: "In addition, Egypt and Uganda had mediated a round of negotiations in Cairo in November 2017 aimed at reunifying the SPLM/A. On 16 November 2017, representatives of the SPLM/A-In Government, the SPLM/A-IO, and the SPLM/A-Former Detainees signed the Cairo Declaration on the Reunification of the Sudan People’s Liberation Movement (SPLM)."

agreement name: Cairo Declaration on the Reunification of the Sudan People’s Liberation Movement (SPLM)
notes_1: "In addition, Egypt and Uganda had mediated a round of negotiations in Cairo in November 2017 aimed at reunifying the SPLM/A. On 16 November 2017, representatives of the SPLM/A-In Government, the SPLM/A-IO, and the SPLM/A-Former Detainees signed the Cairo Declaration on the Reunification of the Sudan People’s Liberation Movement (SPLM)."

agreement name: Agreement on Cessation of Hostilities, Protection of Civilians and Humanitarian Access
notes_1: "The revitalization forum, aimed at restarting peace talks, began in Addis Ababa on 18 December. This round of negotiations led to the conclusion of the Agreement on Cessation of Hostilities, Protection of Civilians and Humanitarian Access on 21 December 2017."

agreement name: Arusha Agreement on the SPLM Reunification Implementation Matrix
notes_1: "Building on the conclusion of the Cairo agreement, another round of negotiations involving the three factions within the SPLM/A was held in Entebbe in December 2017. These negotiations led to the conclusion of the Arusha Agreement on the SPLM Reunification Implementation Matrix on 15 December 2017."

agreement name: Rome Resolution on Monitoring and Verification of the Cessation of Hostilities Agreement
notes_1: "'The (SSOMA) is informing its entire membership. supporters, South Sudanese at large and the International Community that it has together with the Government (...) signed Rome Resolution on Monitoring and Verification of the Cessation of Hostilities Agreement COHA (of) December 2017 under the auspices of the Community of Sant’Egidio,' said the alliance on Friday." Other groups had previously signed this cessation of hostilities agreement in December 2017.
"As part of the Joint Demarcation Committee, the AU mediated between representatives of Sudan and South Sudan between 10 and 13 September 2018. However, no progress was made."

"On 2 January 2018, the Troika – comprising of the US, the UK, and Norway – called on the conflict parties to end their military operations and threatened to impose sanctions on those who would not comply with this call. The IGAD-led mediation process continued in 2018. The second round of the IGAD revitalization forum was held in Addis Ababa between 5 and 16 February 2018, but no agreement was reached."

"A round of proximity talks  was held between the conflict parties in Addis Ababa on 11 and 12 May 2018.  This round of indirect talks was followed by the resumption of the revitalization forum in Addis Ababa from 17 to 23 May 2018. The South Sudan Council of Churches supported this IGAD-led round of negotiations through facilitating dialogue sessions to bridge their differences on the outstanding governance and security issues identified as critical to revitalize the Agreement.  The conflict parties recommitted to the implementation of the cessation of hostilities agreement, but little substantial progress was made. Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed initially led the effort the revitalize the peace process following his election in April 2018."

"The conflict parties engaged in shuttle negotiations in Addis Ababa from 18 to 20 June 2018, but Abiy Ahmed mediated a face-to-face meeting between President Salva Kiir and Riek Machar on the final day of this round of negotiations. This was the first meeting of Kiir and Machar since the resumption of hostilities in July 2016. The following day, on 21 June 2018, the IGAD Assembly of Heads of State and Government mandated Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir to mediate the negotiations. President al-Bashir was supported by Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni."

agreement name: Khartoum Declaration of Agreement between Parties of the Conflict of South Sudan
notes_1: "Face-to-face talks between President Kiir and Machar resumed in Khartoum on 25 June and concluded with the Khartoum Declaration of Agreement between Parties of the Conflict of South Sudan on 27 June. This agreement was also signed by the representatives of the South Sudan Opposition Alliance, the “Former Detainees”, and the other political parties. In the Declaration, the signatories announced a permanent ceasefire, set objectives for transitional security arrangements and signatories to reach an agreement on the IGAD revised bridging proposal, improve infrastructure and basic services in South Sudan and restore oil fields in Unity. The agreement also stipulates a comprehensive ceasefire. This agreement commits the conflict parties to a permanent ceasefire and to finalize a deal on the pending issues in the governance chapter of the 2015 peace agreement. stipulated a “revised bridging proposal” that listed the details of a pre-transitional period. The agreement also includes provisions with regard to the oil, elections, and reconstruction. The agreement thus was meant to pave the way for the formation of an inclusive transitional cabinet. The agreement also called upon the AU and IGAD to deploy protection forces and ceasefire monitors to observe the ceasefire implementation. In addition, the conflict parties agreed to open the humanitarian corridors, release detainees, withdraw troops and militarily disengage."

agreement name: Agreement on Outstanding Issues of Security Arrangements
notes_1: "On 6 July 2018,  following a round of negotiations mediated by  Sudan and Uganda in Khartoum, the conflict parties signed the Agreement on Outstanding Issues of Security Arrangements, which included additional provisions on the ceasefire and the Disarmament, Demobilization, and Reintegration (DDR) process."

agreement name: Agreement on Outstanding issues of Governance
notes_1: "The conflict parties signed the Agreement on Outstanding issues of Governance on 5 August 2018. This agreement supplemented and/or amended previously agreed provisions on political power-sharing through specifying who will hold the key government ministries and positions."

"Building on progress made through the signing of the Agreement on Outstanding issues of Governance, another round of negotiations was held in Khartoum  between  13 and 19 August 2018. These talks mainly focused on the status and incorporation of the documents agreed upon in Addis Ababa and in Khartoum in the preceding months. On 18 August 2018, the mediators circulated a draft revitalized text of the peace agreement to the parties for comment before adjourning for the Eid holidays."

"Building on progress made through the signing of the Agreement on Outstanding issues of Governance, another round of negotiations was held in Khartoum  between  13 and 19 August 2018. These talks mainly focused on the status and incorporation of the documents agreed upon in Addis Ababa and in Khartoum in the preceding months. On 18 August 2018, the mediators circulated a draft revitalized text of the peace agreement to the parties for comment before adjourning for the Eid holidays."

agreement name: Revitalized Agreement on the Resolution of the Conflict in South Sudan
notes_1: "The conflict parties signed a final agreement in Addis Ababa on 12 September 2018, referred to as the Revitalized Agreement on the Resolution of the Conflict in South Sudan (R-ARCSS). While the Troika had been involved in most of the IGAD-led negotiations in 2018, they were excluded from the final rounds of negotiations. The Troika therefore refused to co-sign the R-ARCSS. The agreement outlined a revised comprehensive framework for the transition from conflict. The agreement stipulated the reinstatement of Machar as First Vice President and the establishment of a transitional government in May 2019. In addition, in line with the agreement, Kiir ordered the release of all prisoners of war and detainees in September 2018. Kiir and Machar jointly attended peace celebrations in the capital Juba on October 31 2018, together with the presidents of Sudan, Uganda, Somalia, and Ethiopia, as well as Egypt’s prime minister. Nevertheless, fighting between government forces and the SPLM/A-IO continued throughout the year, though at a lower intensity."

"Throughout 2019, the United Nations Interim Security Force for Abyei (UNSIFA) mediated meetings with officials from Sudan and South Sudan to promote peace in Abyei."

"The R-ARCSS stipulated that Salva Kiir and Riek Machar had to form a unity government by May 2019. On 2 May 2019, IGAD mediated a round of negotiations in Addis Ababa where the conflict parties and the IGAD mediation team agreed to extend the deadline to 12 November 2019. The conflict parties indicated that this extension was needed to complete the necessary transitional security arrangements, including protection for senior government officials, to form the transitional Government. However, follow-up mediation was also needed to address more substantial issues. The International Crisis Group reported on the need for follow-up mediation on the R-ARCSS, stating that “The accord, brokered by Sudan’s Omar al-Bashir and Uganda’s Yoweri Museveni, is not a finished product and requires revision” and that “Additional political deals are necessary on two crucial matters – unifying a national army and resolving bitter disagreements over local boundaries and administration inside South Sudan. Absent such deals, the Kiir-Machar truce may fail its first major test in May 2019, when the two South Sudanese leaders are scheduled to form a unity government.” On 18 October, in a communiqué, the Peace and Security Council of the AU called for the parties’ adherence to the deadline of 12 November. During its visit to South Sudan on 20 October 2019, the UN Security Council also called for adhering to the deadline, but also stressed the need to address outstanding issues. While the Government of South Sudan intended to form the Revitalized Transitional Government of National Unity on 12 November, the SPLM/A-IO called for an extension."

"President Kiir and SPLM/A-IO leader Machar engaged in a face-to-face meeting mediated by Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni on 7 November 2019. The Chair of the Sovereign Council of the Sudan, Lieutenant General Abdel Fattah Abdelrahman Al-Burhan, and the Special Envoy of Kenya to South Sudan were also involved in these talks. The meeting focused on outstanding pre-transitional tasks: transitional security arrangements, the issue of states and their boundaries, and the formation of the Revitalized Transitional Government of National Unity. In order to address these issues, Kiir and Machar agreed on an extension of the pre-transitional period for an additional 100 days, commencing on 12 November 2019."

"President Kiir and SPLM/A-IO leader Machar engaged in a face-to-face meeting mediated by Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni on 7 November 2019. The Chair of the Sovereign Council of the Sudan, Lieutenant General Abdel Fattah Abdelrahman Al-Burhan, and the Special Envoy of Kenya to South Sudan were also involved in these talks. The meeting focused on outstanding pre-transitional tasks: transitional security arrangements, the issue of states and their boundaries, and the formation of the Revitalized Transitional Government of National Unity. In order to address these issues, Kiir and Machar agreed on an extension of the pre-transitional period for an additional 100 days, commencing on 12 November 2019."

notes_1:
"Last November Cirilo was in Rome for meetings with Sant' Edigio officials on ways to reach a negotiated settlement for the armed conflict in the country.

At the end of his two-day discussions, he issued a statement on 20 November 2019 calling on Sant’ Egidio to engage with his alliance, the government and other signatories of the revitalized peace agreement from one side and the regional and international partners on the other side to "make this dialogue process a success".

In a meeting held in Rome during his visit to Rome in March 2019, President Salva Kiir encouraged Sant’ Egidio to continue its efforts for an inclusive peace in his country.

Last November, President Salva Kiir and his main peace partner Riek Machar agreed to delay the formation of the transitional national unity government until next February."
The Troika released a statement pressuring parties in South Sudan to deliver on their commitments to the R-ARCSS and form a national unity government.

"January 11, 2019 (JUBA) - South Sudanese government and three opposition holdout groups have launched discussions on peace in the country organized by the Roman Catholic Sant’ Egidio peace group.

The five-day meeting discusses ways to bring the South Sudan Opposition Alliance led by Thomas Cirilo, South Sudan United Front/ Army, under the leadership of General Paul Malong Awan Anei; and Pagan Amum, the leader of Former Detainees group.

The government’s delegation is led by the former Foreign Minister Barnaba Marial Benjamin who is flanked by the cabinet minister Elia Lomuoro and the head of the National Security Service Akol Koor Kuc.

Several sources confirmed to Sudan Tribune the meeting which started on Friday and is expected to end on Tuesday 14 January."

"GENEVA - Today, on the margins of UNHCR’s annual Executive Committee proceedings, the Foreign Ministers of Sudan and South Sudan held a meeting chaired by the UN High Commissioner for Refugees and attended by the Executive Secretary of the Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD), and the European Union Commissioner for International Partnerships, at which they agreed to begin an IGAD-led regional initiative to seek solutions to protracted displacement in Sudan and South Sudan.

With the recent signing of the Juba Peace Agreement between Sudan’s Transitional Government and the Sudan Revolutionary Front and others on 3 October 2020, and the continued efforts in implementation of the Revitalized Agreement on the Resolution of the Conflict in South Sudan (R-ARCSS) signed on 12 September 2018, all parties present agreed it is a unique opportunity to find lasting solutions for displaced persons from the two countries."
note_2:
"Khartoum – Representatives of the governments of Sudan and the Republic of South Sudan agreed this week on a regional roadmap which will outline the next steps toward medium to long-term solutions for seven million forcibly displaced persons originating from and hosted by the two countries, and other States hosting displaced populations from both countries.

The Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD), currently chaired by Sudan, UNHCR, the Refugee Agency and partners, welcomed the conclusions of this first technical-level meeting, building on the unprecedented opportunity to find lasting solutions for displaced persons from the two countries. The solution strategies will include refugees, IDPs, returnees and host populations and be advanced through the established IGAD Support Platform launched at the Global Refugee Forum."

notes_1:
"South Sudan’s main coalition of donors are calling on leaders to urgently implement remaining tasks of the peace deal before the February 22, 2020 deadline expires.

On Saturday, the United States, Norway, and the United Kingdom, the main countries that have funded peace negotiations in South Sudan, said the country is running out of time to create the transitional unity government.

Known as the TROIKA, the three urged the key principals to the revitalised peace agreement (R-ARCSS) to commit themselves to finalising the pending tasks before the lapse of the extended deadline."

agreement name: Rome Declaration on the Peace Process in South Sudan
notes_1: "Under the auspices of the Community of Sant'Egidio in Rome, and witnessed by IGAD, the government of South Sudan, the South Sudan Opposition Movements Alliance (SSOMA), The SPLM/A-IO, and NDM has signed a peace declaration in which they recommit to the Secession of Hostilities Agreement of December 2017 to avoid confrontation between the signatories and non-signatories parties of South Sudan peace agreement. The parties called for continued and uninterrupted humanitarian access to the local and international organization."

"JUBA - A committee formed to help resolve disputes over the boundaries and number of South Sudan states has turned the issue over to arbitration, adding the issue should not hold up formation of a unity government.

After President Salva Kiir and opposition leader Riek Machar failed to agree on the number of states and their borders during several face-to-face meetings in December, regional bloc IGAD appointed a committee to mediate the issue and come up with a proposal for the parties.

The committee is comprised of South African Deputy President David Mabuza, Kenya’s special envoy to the South Sudan peace talks Kalonzo Musyoka, Uganda’s special envoy to South Sudan Betty Bigombe and IGAD envoy Ismail Waise.

South Africa’s Mabuza, the head of the committee, said in Juba Thursday his group consulted the parties to the deal but could not reach a compromise.

'We all agree that we are going to form the government of national unity, but we are going to subject the question of the number of states to arbitration; a mechanism that is going to take up to 90 days which is the proposal on the table,' Mabuza told VOA's South Sudan in Focus.

Mabuza did not explain what the arbitration entails but said the parties should form a transitional government of national unity government by the February 22 deadline and resolve the issue over states and boundaries later....Mabuza said his committee will draft a final proposal and release it to the public soon.'"
note_2: The term 'other' refers to the arbitration to take place to settle the formation of a national unity government.
note_3: The IGAD-led talks and pressure from international donors, IGOs, and NGOs resulted in the formation of a national unity government on 20th February 2020.

notes_1:
"The United Nations Mission in South Sudan, together with local authorities in Western Lakes, has begun a series of sessions to avoid conflicts in cattle camps ahead of the notoriously resource-scarce and hence violent dry season, which typically runs till early April.

The campaign was launched in Aguoc, one of the biggest cattle camps found in the area. The efforts are made as an early attempt to mitigate cattle raids, revenge attacks and clashes over pastures and water."

"About a thousand citizens of Akon County in the Gogrial area have participated in a peace rally centered around the dissemination of the content of the revitalised peace agreement signed in September 2018.

Organized by the United Nations Mission in South Sudan (UNMISS) in collaboration with the National Pre-Transitional Committee (NPTC), the event brought together a mixed crowd of residents, which also included county commissioners, executive chiefs, women’s organizations and youth groups."
note_2:
"The words of Simon Gardino, acting chairperson of the government-supporting youth attending this peace rally at Yambio Freedom Square, seem to ring true. More than 150 boys and girls seated in the shade of a tree, many of them belonging to the opposition faction of the main political party, the Sudan People’s Liberation Movement, are nodding their agreement.

They come from eight different counties and have gathered for a one-day event, organized by the United Nations Mission in South Sudan in collaboration with the United Nations Development Programme, the local Ministry of Information, Youth, Culture and Sports and the non-governmental organisation Non-Violent Peace Force."
note_3: The term 'other' refers to the UN's organisation of peace rallies across South Sudan.

agreement name: Rome Resolution on Monitoring and Verification of the Cessation of Hostilities Agreement
notes_1:
"February 14, 2020 (JUBA) - The South Sudan Opposition Movements Alliance (SSOMA) Friday has officially taken part in a cessation of hostility deal brokered by the Roman Catholic Sant’ Egidio peace group last January.

"The (SSOMA) is informing its entire membership. supporters, South Sudanese at large and the International Community that it has together with the Government (...) signed Rome Resolution on Monitoring and Verification of the Cessation of Hostilities Agreement COHA (of) December 2017 under the auspices of the Community of Sant’Egidio," said the alliance on Friday.

According to this ceasefire implementation agreement, SSOMA will participate in the Monitoring and Verification mechanism paving the way for further negotiations on the root causes of conflict in South Sudan.
"
note_2:
"April 28, 2020 (JUBA) - The South Sudan Opposition Movements’ Alliance (SSOMA), reiterated its rejection of the revitalized peace pact and IGAD rules of engagement saying they are only committed to the Rome Peace Process.

On Friday 24th of April 2020, Ismail Wais the IGAD Special Envoy for South Sudan told reporters by video conference from Addis Ababa that the Sant’Egidio is "facilitating" discussions between the South Sudanese government and the SSOMA in Rome but the process remains "under the IGAD rules of engagement".
"

notes_1:
"Juba, 20 February 2020: In line with its mandate to promote and enhance peace and security in the Continent, the African Union (AU) Peace and Security Council (PSC) undertook a field mission to the Republic of South Sudan from 18 to 20 February 2020. The Mission took place within the framework of the implementation of various decisions of the Council on the situation in South Sudan. In particular, the Council aimed at evaluating the status of implementation of the Revitalized Agreement on the Resolution of Conflict in the Republic of South Sudan (R-ARCSS) signed on 12 September 2018, given that the Revitalized Transitional Government of National Unity (R-TGONU) is to be formed on 22 February 2020. Furthermore, the Mission aimed at expressing AU’s solidarity with the People and Government of South Sudan during this critical period in the history of the country. In this light, it is worth noting that this is the fourth field mission of the AUPSC to the Republic of South Sudan since October 2016.

The PSC delegation was led by His Excellency Ambassador Mohamed Idriss Farah, Permanent Representative of the Republic of Djibouti to the African Union, in his capacity as the Chairperson of the PSC for the month of February 2020. The PSC delegation comprised representatives of the fifteen Member States, namely: Ambassadors of Algeria, Salah Francis Alhamdi; Angola, Francisco Da Cruz; Burundi, Joel Nkurabagaya; Equatorial Guinea, Cristantos Obama Ondo; Lesotho, Mafa Sejanamane; Morocco, Mohamed Arrouchi; Nigeria, Bankole Adeoye; and Togo, Sebade Toba; as well as Representatives from Gabon, Kenya, Liberia, Rwanda, Sierra Leone and Zimbabwe."

The PSC delegation comprised representatives of the fifteen Member States, namely: Ambassadors of Algeria, Salah Francis Alhamdi; Angola, Francisco Da Cruz; Burundi, Joel Nkurabagaya; Equatorial Guinea, Cristantos Obama Ondo; Lesotho, Mafa Sejanamane; Morocco, Mohamed Arrouchi; Nigeria, Bankole Adeoye; and Togo, Sebade Toba; as well as Representatives from Gabon, Kenya, Liberia, Rwanda, Sierra Leone and Zimbabwe."

"Juba, 20 February 2020: In line with its mandate to promote and enhance peace and security in the Continent, the African Union (AU) Peace and Security Council (PSC) undertook a field mission to the Republic of South Sudan from 18 to 20 February 2020. "Owiny-Kibul, some 60 kilometres from Magwi, towards the Ugandan border, used to be a peaceful village. That was before the Nyachigak military academy and training centre were established in the vicinity, about five years ago. A recent intervention by the United Nations Mission in South Sudan has now restored some of the harmony that had gone missing....Because of these tensions, the UN peacekeeping mission, in collaboration with Christian Relief Aid, a non-governmental organization based in Juba, organized a three-day forum in the area, attracting some 80 women, youth, elders, landlords, chiefs, religious leaders and military officers.

Those in attendance were taught conflict management skills, before moving on to identifying root causes of the bad blood and what to do to improve relations."

"Owiny-Kibul, some 60 kilometres from Magwi, towards the Ugandan border, used to be a peaceful village. That was before the Nyachigak military academy and training centre were established in the vicinity, about five years ago. A recent intervention by the United Nations Mission in South Sudan has now restored some of the harmony that had gone missing....Because of these tensions, the UN peacekeeping mission, in collaboration with Christian Relief Aid, a non-governmental organization based in Juba, organized a three-day forum in the area, attracting some 80 women, youth, elders, landlords, chiefs, religious leaders and military officers.

Those in attendance were taught conflict management skills, before moving on to identifying root causes of the bad blood and what to do to improve relations."
The UNMISS deployed peacekeepers in rural regions to prevent escalating intercommunal clashes and find peaceful resolutions.
As the main donors of the South Sudanese peace process, the Troika (US, UK, Norway) urged the South Sudanese government to appoint state governors to address the growing violence across South Sudan.
As the main donors of the South Sudanese peace process, the Troika (US, UK, Norway) urged the South Sudanese government to appoint state governors to address the growing violence across South Sudan.
As the main donors of the South Sudanese peace process, the Troika (US, UK, Norway) urged the South Sudanese government to appoint state governors to address the growing violence across South Sudan.

"Keeping up momentum regarding the ongoing peace process in South Sudan despite nation-wide COVID-19 restrictions was at the heart of a recent day-long event organized by UNMISS Civil Affairs in Western Bahr el Ghazal. The forum aimed at widening engagement with and understanding of the Revitalized Peace Agreement by political stakeholders, including representatives of the Sudan People's Liberation Movement (SPLM) and the Sudan People’s Liberation Movement-in Opposition (SPLM-IO), religious and community leaders as well as civil society actors in the region.

Participants agreed on developing communication modalities that would help them continue to work together for the cause of sustainable peace. These included technology-based options such as using social media applications and short messaging systems to foster ongoing dialogues that, ultimately, will serve to bring social cohesion and reconciliation to Western Bahr el Ghazal, a region that has been devastated by conflict."

"Thousands of families have had their lives devastated by a vicious cycle of fighting and revenge attacks that have plagued the Jonglei region of South Sudan for the past six months….In an effort to end the conflict, the United Nations Mission in South Sudan brought together political leaders at the national and state level as well as community elders, civil society and other key stakeholders for mediation and peace talks at a forum in Juba.

Opening the event, the Special Representative of the Secretary-General, David Shearer said that every community in the region had suffered from the violence....The SRSG pointed to a number of ways that UNMISS can support the mediation effort. These include political and logistical support for Governors to conduct peace talks across the State, providing peacekeepers to monitor buffer zones between the groups, increasing the capacity of local police and helping develop infrastructure to address underlying causes of the violence, such as building new roads, schools, and water points.

However, he said there has to be a genuine willingness among all parties to work constructively together to end the fighting first."

"September 25, 2020 (JUBA) -The alliance of South Sudanese holdout groups, SOMMA, has suspended the South Sudan United Front (SSUF) of General Paul Malong ahead of the resumption of peace talks in Rome next October….Reliable sources told Sudan Tribune that the alliance had been observed that General Malong established a secondary channel of communication with the Sant’Egidio mediators.

Also, the sources claimed that Malong and Kiir resumed contacts and discuss regularly opposition plans for the peace process.

The government and SSOMA are scheduled to resume peace talks next month.

A new round of peace talks will be held in Rome from 5 to 9 October.

It s not clear how the mediation will organize the upcoming talks.

The alliance consists of the Real Sudan People’s Liberation Movement (R-SPLM), National Salvation Front (NAS). South Sudan United Front (SSUF) and the United Democratic Revolutionary Movement/Army (UNDRM/A), National Democratic Movement-PF (NDM-PF), and Sudan National Movement for Change (SSNMC)."

"The Legislative arm of the RTGoNU is yet to be reconstituted. The 36th Extraordinary Meeting of the IGAD Heads of State and Government held in July 2020 appealed to the President of the Republic of South Sudan to dissolve the current Transitional National Legislative Assembly (TNLA) before 26th July 2020; and the Parties to reconstitute the TNLA within seven (7) days of its dissolution. However, the TNLA is yet to be dissolved and its expansion and reconstitution has been delayed. The Summit also called upon the R-TGoNU to take remedial measures to immediately rectify the alterations made to the Constitutional Amendment Bill. These measures were initiated by the NCAC in order to rectify the alterations and submitted to the Minister of Justice and Constitutional Affairs for review....The RJMEC Interim Chairperson addressed virtual meetings of the IGAD Heads of State and Governments and the African Union Peace and Security Council (AUPSC), in which he outlined the current status of implementation and recommended that: the Parties move to speedily appoint the Upper Nile governor; the reconstitution of the TNLA be undertaken immediately; the training, graduation and redeployment of the Necessary Unified Forces move ahead; the authorities initiate dialogue at the grassroots level in order to address intercommunal violence; and the Africa Union continue to pursue establishment of the Hybrid Court. In addition, the RJMEC leadership held meetings with H.E Salva Kiir, President, Dr Riek Machar Teny, First Vice President, and the four Vice Presidents of the Republic of South Sudan."

These measures were initiated by the NCAC in order to rectify the alterations and submitted to the Minister of Justice and Constitutional Affairs for review....The RJMEC Interim Chairperson addressed virtual meetings of the IGAD Heads of State and Governments and the African Union Peace and Security Council (AUPSC), in which he outlined the current status of implementation and recommended that: the Parties move to speedily appoint the Upper Nile governor; the reconstitution of the TNLA be undertaken immediately; the training, graduation and redeployment of the Necessary Unified Forces move ahead; the authorities initiate dialogue at the grassroots level in order to address intercommunal violence; and the Africa Union continue to pursue establishment of the Hybrid Court. In addition, the RJMEC leadership held meetings with H.E Salva Kiir, President, Dr Riek Machar Teny, First Vice President, and the four Vice Presidents of the Republic of South Sudan."

"The Legislative arm of the RTGoNU is yet to be reconstituted. The 36th Extraordinary Meeting of the IGAD Heads of State and Government held in July 2020 appealed to the President of the Republic of South Sudan to dissolve the current Transitional National Legislative Assembly (TNLA) before 26th July 2020; and the Parties to reconstitute the TNLA within seven (7) days of its dissolution. However, the TNLA is yet to be dissolved and its expansion and reconstitution has been delayed. The Summit also called upon the R-TGoNU to take remedial measures to immediately rectify the alterations made to the Constitutional Amendment Bill. These measures were initiated by the NCAC in order to rectify the alterations and submitted to the Minister of Justice and Constitutional Affairs for review....The RJMEC Interim Chairperson addressed virtual meetings of the IGAD Heads of State and Governments and the African Union Peace and Security Council (AUPSC), in which he outlined the current status of implementation and recommended that: the Parties move to speedily appoint the Upper Nile governor; the reconstitution of the TNLA be undertaken immediately; the training, graduation and redeployment of the Necessary Unified Forces move ahead; the authorities initiate dialogue at the grassroots level in order to address intercommunal violence; and the Africa Union continue to pursue establishment of the Hybrid Court. In addition, the RJMEC leadership held meetings with H.E Salva Kiir, President, Dr Riek Machar Teny, First Vice President, and the four Vice Presidents of the Republic of South Sudan."

"In order to support the implementation of the revitalized peace agreement, advance the unification of of army, the Chinese government has successively provided a number of material assistance to South Sudan since last year. On October 26, 2020, the handover ceremony of the second batch of food aid was held in Juba. H.E. Hua Ning, Chinese Ambassador to South Sudan, and Hon. Stephen Par, Minister of Peace Building of South Sudan and Secretary of National Transitional Committee(NTC) attended the ceremony.

Ambassador Hua Ning said that the peace process in South Sudan has entered a new stage, the training and redeployment of unified forces remains an important and urgent task. In the face of COVID-19, the deteriorating economic situation, and the frequent occurrence of natural disasters, relevant parties of South Sudan continued peace talks through dialogue and consultation which brought some positive progress. The Chinese government and people support the peace process from the very beginning, in a hope that South Sudan will restore peace and stability at an early date. China takes the lead in providing material assistance to South Sudan's unified forces building, all assistance promised have been delivered. Ambassador Hua called on all relevant parties of South Sudan to continue to show their political will, unite to overcome difficulties, speed up the implementation of the revitalized peace agreement, and build a unified people's forces to serve the country and all the people. China will continue its support for the peace process, we also encourage the international community to provide concrete assistance to South Sudan."

"The platform in question was a recent peace forum organized by UNMISS and Community Empowerment for Progress Organization (CEPO) which brought together 20 representatives from women’s groups, youth organizations, civil society, displaced persons as well as traditional and religious leaders across Western Bahr El Ghazal.

Participants were taught basic skills in promoting a peaceful approach to conflict resolution. The objective—to enhance social cohesion and ensure that peace actors work from the ground up so that implementation of the Revitalized Peace Agreement across South Sudan acquires momentum."
note_2: The term 'other' refers to the UN's organisation of an open forum.

notes_1: The term 'other' refers to the UN's support and facilitation of the National Dialogue Conference (NDC) in South Sudan, organised by the South Sudan's steering committee for the NDC.

"Traditional leaders in Yambio have been taken through every chapter of South Sudan’s Revitalized Peace Agreement, not least to fully understand the obligation of the state government and community leaders to inform communities about its content.

“I am happy to acquire this knowledge about the different provisions of the peace agreement, especially chapter five, which talks more about the role of the chiefs and the local government to keep citizens informed,” said Edward Mumbasa, acting paramount chief in Yambio County.

Organized by the United Nations Mission in South Sudan and the United Nations Development Programme, the two-day forum brought together more than 30 chiefs from different villages and communities. Among the issues discussed were the provisions of the revitalized peace agreement related to healing and reconciliation, the establishment of a hybrid court and and enterprise development fund."

"(ANSA 14 October): A new commitment by the two warring parties in South Sudan to silence the weapons in a renewed hope of peace. Mediator of the meeting held in Rome, the Community of Sant'Egidio, which will also organize the next military and political events, both scheduled in the Italian capital respectively from 9 to 12 November and 30 of the same month at the Community headquarters.

The opposition will be guaranteed to be part of the monitoring relating to the ceasefire with the first meeting, a workshop of military commanders, whereas the second one will lead to the signing of a declaration of principles of a political nature. Federalism, the constitution, security, land allocation and reconciliation are among the important issues on which to reach an agreement."

I was disappointed to see the reports of clashes between the SSPDF and the NAS forces recently, but it’s encouraging to see parties back negotiating about SSOMA possibly being included in the CTSAMVM board by the New Year, which means that they’ll have their activities monitored by CTSAMVM."

"December 11, 2020 (JUBA) - The United States, United Kingdom and Norway have commended South Sudanese leaders for agreeing on the long-awaited formation of the Transitional National Legislative Assembly (TNLA).

On Wednesday, South Sudan’s parties to the revitalized peace agreement broke the stalemate on formation of states governments and reconstitution national assembly....According to the minister, the Transitional Government of Nation Unity (TGoNU) would hold a national conference in Juba for all communities of Upper Nile State to discuss ways and means of ending tribal differences in the state, prior to the final decision on the appointment of their governor.

Meanwhile, Stuart Symington, the U.S special envoy said representatives of the TROIKA nations pledged to support the peace process in South Sudan."

"The IGAD Special Envoy for South Sudan, Ambassador Ismail Wais, called for allinclusive peacebuilding, noting that broad participation is integral to ensure a strong protection environment and durable solutions for those displaced. “The priorities for reconstruction of South Sudan will be determined by displaced communities through their own lived experiences.”

Delivering a presentation virtually from Adjumani in Uganda, Maia Keven Juliet, a refugee from South Sudan, urged leaders “Not to give up. Peace is a process,” and called for widespread awareness of the peace process among displaced communities. Speaking on behalf of the internally displaced community in Benitu, Gok Diang Chuong called for more opportunities for displaced persons to participate in decision making, including in the formation of the transitional government, restoration of housing, land and property rights, as well as the establishment of a commission for truth, justice, reconciliation and healing.

Joining these representatives of South Sudan’s displaced communities, speakers from the United Nations, the government of South Sudan and civil society, referenced the pledges made at the Global Refugee Forum in 2019, as well as the desire to support solutions in a dignified and suitable way. This includes the creation of conditions on the ground to support return, while also ensuring the centrality of human rights in all phases of displacement, allowing affected persons to decide on solutions that are best for them.

Building on the good practices of the National Dialogue held in Juba in October of this year which provided a platform for over 40 displaced persons to be heard, as well as the affirmation within the R-ARCSS itself which critically, provides for solutions for refugees, IDPs and returnees, the meeting concluded with a call for the development of a framework to increase meaningful participation of conflict affected communities. This includes the establishment of a national taskforce and platform dedicated to ensuring displaced communities participate in peace building and reconciliation at state, regional and national level, along with the prioritisation of legislation to address protection concerns.

The webinar was organised by IGAD in coordination with UNHCR and with the support of GP 20, a multi-stakeholder initiative launched for the 20th anniversary of the Guiding Principles on Internal Displacement."

"[A]t the national level, UNMISS is working to achieve underlying agreement on vital aspects of the peace process….and most particularly over the last few weeks – on the constitution and putting the constitution in place."

"YEI, SOUTH SUDAN - With an eye toward ending intercommunal violence that killed dozens of people last month in Central Equatoria state, South Sudanese religious leaders and civil society activists have organized direct peace and reconciliation talks between various communities.

Some meetings already have taken place in rural villages of Terekeka County and included chiefs, women, youth, farmers, and cattle camp leaders."
UNMISS has led consultations, mediation, and peacekeeping efforts in rural areas around South Sudan to prevent and deal with violence associated with the migration of cattle herders and their cattle.
note_2:
"MANYANG MAYOM To counter the effects of continuing tensions and outbreaks of intercommunal conflict in the greater Tonj area of Warrap state, UNMISS Civil Affairs recently organized a peace campaign in Ngapagok payam (administrative division) located in Tonj east.

The event, which included awareness-raising on peaceful reconciliation, the need for social cohesion and the role of the peacekeeping mission in building durable peace across South Sudan, was attended by hundreds of community members.

Most importantly, with seasonal cattle migration taking place across the world’s newest country, a focus for discussions and sensitization was the Marial Bai cattle movement agreement which was signed in November 2016."
note_3:
"MANYANG MAYOM/FILIP ANDERSSON

Dry season in South Sudan means that a large number of herders and their thousands of cattle migrate in search of water and new pastures. To minimize the related conflicts that occur, the United Nations Mission in South Sudan has embarked on a series of peace dialogues in affected areas, most recently in Tonj South in Warrap State."
note_4:
"PRIYANKA CHOWDHURY “As a mission, our primary goal has always been to prevent violence breaking out and to protect civilians when needed,” says David Shearer, the top United Nations envoy in South Sudan and head of the peacekeeping operation, UNMISS.

“We’re currently in the middle of the dry season here,” he continues. “It’s always a tricky time because nomadic herders start moving their livestock to find grazing land and water. This cross-country movement creates tensions with those farming settled lands. Herders sometimes allow cattle to graze on cultivated crops and farmers retaliate to protect their resources which can lead to conflict, loss of life and displacement,” reveals SRSG Shearer.

To reduce the risk of violence, UNMISS peacekeepers have adopted a more mobile approach by establishing temporary operating bases near seasonal cattle migration routes.

In Cueibet, a county in the Lakes region, Nepalese peacekeepers serving with UNMISS established a temporary operating base in November 2020 as part of a proactive measure to build confidence among local communities and deter potential skirmishes."

notes_1: "More than 30 local chiefs residing in Malakal town or in the peacekeeping mission’s protection of civilians site in that Upper Nile city have learnt valuable conflict management skills and skills to promote reconciliation and social cohesion in and between their communities."

"Early every year, the nomadic people of Misseriya in Sudan and their herds of cattle make the long journey south to Aweil East County in South Sudan. They come in search of water and pasture, but a scarcity of such resources frequently leads to tensions and sometimes violent clashes with cattle herders in the Dinka Malual host communities.

This year has so far been no exception, with the recent killing of a Misseriya tribesman resulting in the closure of the border post between the two countries.

To reduce tensions, the United Nations Mission in South Sudan (UNMISS) in collaboration with its peace partners and the government have hosted a peace and pre-migration conference between the two groups. The representatives who met in Aweil have now agreed on a series of resolutions and recommendations to promote peace and freedom of movement for all – without carrying guns.

“Any person found possessing a gun or ammunition inside South Sudanese territory shall be arrested and subjected to legal procedures,” said William Kolong, the Regional Peace Coordinator, reading out the resolutions."

RJMEC under the auspices of IGAD has been in the process of overseeing the formation of a Constitutional committee to hold a constitution-making workshop. This was set to be held on 1-3 February 2021, however the South Sudanese government had not provided a list of participants, thus postponing the workhsop.
note_2: "With respect to the Permanent Constitution-making process envisaged under Chapter VI of the R-ARCSS, the RJMEC has scheduled the workshop to take place towards the end of May 2021. This was made possible following nominations by all the Parties of their representatives to the workshop. During the workshop, the Parties are expected to agree on the details of conducting the permanent constitution-making process, which outcome shall form the basis of the legislations to be enacted."

notes_1:
"Juba – The Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD), UNHCR, the Refugee Agency and partners, applaud progress toward lasting solutions for forcibly displaced persons as national consultations took place last week in Juba, South Sudan.

The two day event successfully marked another milestone for South Sudan’s implementation of the Sudan and South Sudan Solutions Initiative, under the auspices of IGAD, following the establishment of the Inter-Ministerial National Technical Committee (NTC) and hosting the second High-Level technical meeting in Juba in early January.
The workshop was attended by over 70 persons, both virtually and in person, including representation of those internally displaced, refugee returnees and host communities in Bentiu,
Bor, Jamjang, Maban, Malakal, Wau and Yambio. Refugees hosted in Kenya, Sudan, and Uganda also actively participated virtually."

"DENIS LOURO OLIVER

“For us to be more resilient, we should let idle youth work at farms to produce more food,” suggested Victoria Yatoma, Executive Director of the Nile Sisters Development Organization.

Ms. Yatoma made her recommendation at a workshop preceding the Annual Learning Forum, which is a joint programme launched under the umbrella of the Partnership for Recovery and Resilience in South Sudan.

Two gatherings in the Western Equatoria State towns of Yambio and Nzara, supported by the United Nations Mission in South Sudan, brought together representatives of youth, women, religious group, traditional leaders, business communities and state actors to discuss ways forward on how to boost recovery and resilience in the wake of civil war, COVID-19 and other stressful factors."

"SAMSON LIBERTY

“We have suffered from numerous conflicts and it is important for us to know how to resolve these amicably, especially disagreements with nomadic herders,” says Anyisa Pagan Amum.

Mr. Amum was speaking at an UNMISS-facilitated peace forum held in Kodok, Upper Nile state, where more than 30 representatives from civil society organizations, women, youth and traditional leaders came together to discuss building social cohesion, reconciliation and harmony among local communities here.

Kodok, located within Fashoda county, was devastated by the civil war which took place in South Sudan in 2013. Many people fled their homes at the time, but now with a peace deal and a transitional government of national unity in place, they are slowly returning to their families and beginning the painstaking process of rebuilding their lives.

The two-day training hosted by the mission’s Civil Affairs Division on 13-14 April 2021, therefore, aimed at empowering participants with basic conflict-management training. It also focused on building relationships between"

"Almost a decade later, it has a ceasefire and peace deal in place and is now beginning the journey towards a new constitution that will ultimately pave the way for free and fair elections.

A two-day workshop, sponsored by regional and international partners, was launched in the capital Juba by the country's President and political parties.

"Since this workshop is to develop a roadmap for the first permanent constitution of the Republic of the independent South Sudan, it is absolutely critical that it reflects the aspirations of our people for freedom, equality, justice and prosperity for all," said President Salva Kiir at the opening event.

The Prime Minister of Sudan and Chair of the Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD), Abdalla Hamdok, expressed his support and acknowledged the complexity of the process ahead.
"
